questions.question: Which of the following is NOT one of the major criteria included in the CASPAR (Classification Criteria for Psoriatic Arthritis) for diagnosing psoriatic arthritis in patients with psoriasis?

options.A: Evidence of psoriasis (current history, or family history)

questions.explanation: Correct answer: D)Presence of rheumatoid nodules. Explanation: According to the Classification of Psoriatic Arthritis (CASPAR) criteria for diagnosing psoriatic arthritis, a patient must accumulate 3 or more points from the given categories CASPAR criteria Criteria Points Current Psoriasis 2 History of psoriasis 1 Psoriasis in a first or second I degree relative. 1 Typical psoriatic nail involvement. 1 A negative test for rheumatoid factor. 1 Current dactylitis. 1 History of dactylitis. 1 Radiological evidence of juxta I articular new bone formation. 1 Reference: Rook’s Textbook of Dermatology, 9th Edition, Chapter 35, Section 45

questions.question: A 12y/o girl comes to the OPD with her parents complaining of multiple small, erythematous, scaly plaques on the trunk with a characteristic raindrop appearance 10 days after a streptococcal throat infection. An image of her lesions is given below. What is the appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) Penicillin Explanation: The presentation is classical of guttate psoriasis , often seen in children and adolescents . It typically occurs 1–3 weeks after a streptococcal pharyngitis or upper respiratory tract infection. The appropriate treatment includes: Eradication of the triggering streptococcal infection using penicillin (or amoxicillin) . Topical therapies (like corticosteroids or emollients) may help skin symptoms but do not address the underlying cause. Reassurance may be needed, but antibiotic therapy is essential in acute, post-streptococcal guttate psoriasis. Clinical Features of Guttate Psoriasis: Feature Description Age group Common in children and young adults Trigger Post-streptococcal pharyngitis (esp. Streptococcus pyogenes ) Lesion morphology Multiple, small (<1 cm), erythematous, scaly plaques ("drop-like") Distribution Trunk, proximal limbs Course May resolve spontaneously or evolve into chronic plaque psoriasis Topical corticosteroids (Option A) : Incorrect as first-line monotherapy in acute guttate psoriasis post-infection. Can be used adjunctively ,

questions.question: An orthopaedic surgeon shows you an X-ray of HLA B-27 positive female with seronegative arthritis and psoriatic skin lesions, and you observe the following deformity. What is the eponym given to this deformity?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: B)Pencil-in-cup deformity Explanation: Pencil-in-cup deformity The "pencil-in-cup" deformity is a characteristic radiographic finding in patients with psoriatic arthritis. Psoriatic arthritis occurs mainly in HLA B-27 positive patients and is seronegative . It results from erosive changes at the joint margins, leading to bony proliferation and destruction, causing the proximal bone to taper into the distal bone. It is often seen in the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joints and is indicative of severe joint damage in psoriatic arthritis. The tapered phalanx is also called the ‘mouse ear deformity.’ Ivory phalanx (Option A) occurs due to new bone formation in psoriatic arthritis ; the phalanx may appear whiter due to sclerosis. Boutonniere deformity (Option C) is commonly seen in rheumatoid arthritis, and involves flexion of the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joint with hyperextension of the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint. Fraying (Option D): Irregularity and thinning of the cortex of long bones, particularly at the metaphyses, resulting in a fuzzy or frayed appearance seen in vitamin C

questions.question: A 10 year old boy presents to you with scaly, red follicular plaques over his body. He also has areas near his axilla that are spared from these lesions . What is the most likely histopathological pattern that is characteristic of his disease?

options.C: Checkerboard pattern with alternate areas of hyperkeratosis and parakeratosis

questions.explanation: Correct answer: C)Checkerboard pattern with alternate areas of hyperkeratosis and parakeratosis also called islands of sparing , the diagnosis is Pityriasis Rubra Pilaris (PRP) . Pityriasis Rubra Pilaris is characterized by a histopathological finding known as the checkerboard pattern, which consists of alternate areas of hyperkeratosis (thickening of the stratum corneum) and parakeratosis (retention of nuclei in the stratum corneum). Treatment includes topical agents, the same as that used in psoriasis including topical corticosteroids and emollients. Hyperkeratosis Parakeratosis Acanthosis and spongiosis (Option A) are histopathological findings commonly seen in conditions such as psoriasis and eczema, but they are not characteristic of PRP. Elongation of rete ridges (Option B) is a histological feature typically associated with psoriasis rather than PRP. Lichenoid infiltrate with Civatte bodies (Option D ) is a histopathological finding seen in lichen planus, which is a different dermatological disorder unrelated to PRP.

questions.question: A 24 year old girl with psoriatic skin lesions comes to the dermatology OPD with complaints of joint pain and worsening of her skin lesions. You want to use a single agent for managing both her skin disease and arthritis. Which of the following would you use?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: A)Methotrexate Explanation: Methotrexate inhibit s dihydrofolate reductase, thereby disrupting folate metabolism and interfering with DNA synthesis, leading to decreased proliferation of skin cells. It also decreases the production of inflammatory cytokines eg. TNF-alpha and ILs, thereby reducing inflammation in the joints. It is currently the most recommended single agent for managing both psoriatic arthritis and skin lesions. Dosage: 7.5-25 mg/week via oral/subcutaneous route. Common side effects of methotrexate include: Gastrointestinal symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. Hepatotoxicity necessitates regular monitoring of liver function tests. Bone marrow suppression leads to anemia, leukopenia, and thrombocytopenia and requires monitoring through regular blood counts. Long-term use: hepatotoxicity, pulmonary toxicity (including interstitial pneumonitis), and renal toxicity. Oral corticosteroids (Option B): They are used at times to control acute flares of psoriatic arthritis. However, they are not preferred as a single agent for managing both skin disease and arthritis, considering their potential to cause instability of cutaneous psoriasis due to reactivation after stopping. Cyclosporine (Option C): It acts by inhibiting IL-2, a key cytokine involved in immune response modulation. Often termed a " crisis drug ," it is utilized to manage severe acute episodes of various immune-mediated disorders. Due to its potential for adverse effects like hyperlipidemia and hypertension, cyclosporin is not used long-term for psoriasis with psoriatic arthritis. Leflunomide (Option D) may be effective for arthritis, but it does not adequately address the skin disease aspect.

questions.question: Which of the following medications would not be used for treating a patient with moderate to severe psoriasis?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: D)Tocilizumab Explanation: Tocilizumab - It is a biological drug that targets the interleukin-6(IL-6) receptor, used primarily in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis, giant cell arteritis, and juvenile idiopathic arthritis. The characteristics of various topical treatments are shown in the table below Aspect Topical Corticosteroids Vitamin D analogues (Option B) Tazarotene (Option C) Coal tar Mechanism of Action Local anti-inflammatory action Regulate epidermal keratinocyte proliferation. Regulate immune cell function. Modulating keratinocyte differentiation and proliferation. Anti-inflammatory Antiproliferative Frequency Once daily Once or twice daily Side Effects Cutaneous atrophy Tachyphylaxis Rebound flare Systemic absorption Local irritation Erythema Scaling. Odor Staining properties Inconvenience of application Calcipotriene (also known as calcipotriol ) and dithranol are examples of vitamin D analogs commonly used to treat psoriasis. Adalimumab (Option A) is a tumor necrosis factor (TNF) inhibitor. It works by blocking the action of TNF. It is used to treat various autoimmune conditions such as psoriasis, psoriatic arthritis, rheumatoid arthritis, and ankylosing spondylitis. Reference: Rook’s Textbook of Dermatology, 9th Edition, Chapter 35, Section 23

questions.question: Which of the following spectrums of UV Light is most commonly used in the treatment of psoriasis?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: B)UVB Explanation: UVB therapy, particularly narrow-band UVB , is the recommended first-line and most commonly used therapy for most patients with moderate to severe psoriasis. Narrow-band UVB has a high effectiveness and tolerability compared to other UV spectra, such as broadband UVB and UVA (PUVA therapy). The mechanism of NB-UVB is cutaneous immunomodulation by Increasing vitamin D Induction of apoptosis of T cells Reduction of epidermal hyperproliferation Wavelengths of various UV spectra are given in the image below. UVA(Option A): While UVA therapy (PUVA) has been used in the treatment of psoriasis, narrow-band UVB is preferred now. PUVA therapy is associated with concerns regarding long-term side effects, including an increased risk of skin cancer. UVC (Option C) exposure can be harmful to the skin and is not indicated for therapeutic purposes in psoriasis management. UVD (Option D): "UVD light" is not a recognized term in the context of ultraviolet radiation. The standard terminology for ultraviolet radiation includes UVA, UVB, and UVC. Reference: Rook’s Textbook of Dermatology, 9th Edition, Chapter 35, Section 25

questions.question: You are called by an ObGyn resident for the referral of care of a G2P1 woman with a known history of psoriasis, currently in her 2nd trimester. She is complaining of fever and malaise, and examination shows the following findings: What could be a possible fetal complication in this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: C)Low birth weight Explanation: This patient with a known history of psoriasis and an image showing healing pustular lesions most likely has impetigo herpetifromis. Impetigo herpetiformis is a rare and severe form of pustular psoriasis that typically occurs during pregnancy or postpartum. It is characterized by widespread pustular eruptions with systemic symptoms such as fever, malaise, and electrolyte imbalances. A possible fetal complication in this patient with impetigo herpetiformis during the third trimester could be low birth weight , as the condition is associated with significant maternal and fetal risks, including i ntrauterine growth restriction and placental insufficiency . Treatment includes Admit the patient IV Steroids/ Cyclosporine Strict monitoring with appropriate IV fluids Avoiding aggravating factors No complications (Option A): Impetigo

questions.question: A patient with a fever of 103°C and pain all over his body comes to your clinic. He recently went to a high-profile medical spa, where he was treated with oral medication for his chronic psoriasis. He was elated with the complete resolution during treatment but woke up with a fever, malaise, and pain three days ago. Skin examination is given in the image below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: A) Pustular psoriasis Explanation: The diagnosis of the image is pustular psoriasis (a type of unstable psoriasis) characterized by the presence of multiple sterile, non-infectious pus-filled blisters on erythematous skin, forming a characteristic 'Lakes of pus' appearance. This condition can occur due to the abrupt cessation of systemic corticosteroids , leading to rebound flare-ups of psoriasis. Since it affects the whole body, it is also called Acute generalized pustular psoriasis or Von Zumbusch psoriasis. Aggravating factors: Withdrawal of steroids Coal tar Pregnancy Stress Classification of Unstable Psoriasis: Erythrodermic psoriasis (Option B) is another variant of unstable psoriasis that presents with erythema and scales covering more than 90% of the body surface. Psoriasis Vulgaris (Option C) also known as plaque psoriasis, is the most common form of psoriasis. It is characterized by raised, red patches of skin covered with silvery scales. Rupioid psoriasis (Option D) is a severe

questions.question: A 20 year old male patient comes to your dermatology OPD complaining of non-itchy lesions on the back of his elbows, shins, and knees. On examination, you find scaly lesions that exhibit the Auspitz sign, as shown in the image below. Which of the following processes is responsible for this patient's lesions?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: A) Th1-mediated disorder Explanation: The Auspitz sign, characterized by pinpoint bleeding in the areas where the lesion is scraped with a glass slide, is commonly associated with psoriasis, as depicted in the image above. Psoriasis occurs via Th1-mediated immune responses , which are also involved in the pathogenesis of lichen planus. The inflammatory modulators involved in a Th1 response are: INF- γ (Th1 cells) TNF- α (Th1 cells) Th-17 (IL-17) (Th17 cells) Th-22 (IL-22) (Th22 cells) A detailed depiction of the pathogenesis is given in the image below. Immune cells Immunomodulators Examples Th2 response (Option B) T helper 2 (Th2) cells Eosinophils Mast cells IL-4 IL-13 Atopic dermatitis (eczema) IgE response (Option C) B cells (producing IgE antibodies) Mast cells IL-10 Allergic contact dermatitis Mast cell activation (Option D) Mast cells

questions.question: A 24 year old male patient presents to you with joint pain in his fingers. He is currently a fashion student at NIFT and shares that other students bully him for having a few ‘sausage fingers.’ What type of arthritis would you most suspect in this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: A) Asymmetrical oligoarthritis Explanation: In psoriatic arthritis (PsA), inflammation can affect the joints closest to the fingernails and toenails (DIP), resulting in swelling and inflammation. This inflammation can lead to the characteristic appearance of swollen and sausage-like fingers or toes. The image below is that of sausage toes. According to Moll and Wright's classification of psoriatic arthritis, the percentage of patients with different types of psoriatic arthritis is as follows: Clinical pattern of presentation Percentage of patients Asymmetrical oligoarthritis 50% Symmetrical polyarthritis 40% Distal interphalangeal arthritis 5% Arthritis mutilans 5% Spinal column or axial involvement 40% The table above proves that the most common type of arthritis associated with psoriasis is asymmetric oligoarthritis (50%). Distal interphalangeal arthritis (Option B) affects 5% of patients with psoriatic arthritis. Spinal column or axial involvement (Option C) affects 40% of patients. Arthritis mutilans (Option D) is a severe form of PsA characterized by destructive joint changes, but it is relatively rare with a prevalence of 5%.

questions.question: On examination of a specific finding in the nail, a dermatology professor confirms the presence of nail psoriasis. Which of these findings helped the professor establish this diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) Oil drop sign Explanation: The Oil drop sign refers to small, yellowish-orange discolorations seen beneath the nail plate, resembling drops of oil, and is highly specific for nail psoriasis. It is the most specific sign of psoriasis with a specificity of ~98% It occurs due to nail bed parakeratosis and psoriasiform hyperplasia It occurs just before onycholysis Important findings in nail psoriasis are (Mnemonic: POLISH) Pits Onycholysis Leukonychia Salmon patch Subungual Hyperkeratosis Pitting of the nails (Option A): While pitting is the most common finding in nail psoriasis, it is not as specific as the oil drop sign. Other diseases where pitting of nails is seen are : Alopecia Areata , Onychomycosis , Darier's disease , Hailey-Hailey disease etc. Onycholysis (Option C) or separation of the nail plate from the nail bed, can occur in various nail conditions including trauma and onychomycosis (fungal nail infection), not just nail psoriasis. Subungual hyperkeratosis (Option D) refers to the thickening of the skin under the nail, which can also be seen in other nail disorders including eczema and hyperkeratosis, and is not specific to nail psoriasis.

questions.question: During your infectious disease rotation, you examine a 37 year old diabetic female with non-itchy lesions under both her breasts in the ward. The patient mentions that her lesions are non-itchy and exacerbate during the winter. They are salmon in colour, as shown in the image below. What is your next step in management?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) Local application of corticosteroids Explanation: These lesions are consistent with flexural or inverse psoriasis, characterized by non-itchy, salmon-coloured plaques in flexural areas like under the breasts. As it is a variant of psoriasis, local corticosteroids help reduce inflammation and alleviate symptoms. It's important to differentiate flexural psoriasis from candidal intertrigo, which is also common in similar areas but is itchy and lacks the characteristic bilaterally symmetrical scaly appearance. Characteristics Flexural Psoriasis Candidal Intertrigo Image Colour Salmon Red, erythematous Symmetry Bilaterally symmetrical Asymmetrical Satellite lesions are seen Symptoms Not pruritic Pruritic Exacerbation Cold environment Warm, humid environment Treatment Topical corticosteroids and emollients Topical and oral antifungals Reassurance (Option A) alone may not be sufficient as the patient's condition requires treatment to alleviate symptoms and prevent exacerbations. Oral fluconazole (Option B) is not the appropriate choice because the lesions are not indicative of a fungal infection; they lack the typical features of candidiasis or tinea. Oral corticosteroids (Option D) are not needed as the lesion is restricted to her breast region. Topical steroids can be applied to the specific site to resolve the lesion.

questions.question: An immigrant laborer comes to your Sunday volunteer clinic complaining of thickening of the skin on his scalp. The lesions are not itchy, cross the hairline, and are not associated with loss of hair as shown in the given image. What is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: A) Pityriasis amiantacea Explanation: Pityriasis amiantacea is a scalp condition characterized by th e formation of thick, asbestos-like scales that adhere to the hair shafts. While the lesions are typically not itchy , they could cause hair loss if left untreated. Can be secondary to an underlying inflammatory skin disorder such as: Psoriasis Lichen simplex Scalp infections Treatment Topical corticosteroids Keratolytic agents Seborrheic dermatitis (Option B) is a scalp condition with red, itchy , greasy scales that affects areas rich in sebaceous glands, like the scalp, face, and upper trunk it can be caused by the fungi Malassezia furfur. Pityriasis

questions.question: During Dermatology grand rounds, a professor asks you to demonstrate the signs observed in patients with psoriasis. What is the order in which you will see these signs while scraping the lesion with the blunt end of a glass slide?

options.A: Grattage sign, Berkeley’s Membrane, Auspitz Sign
options.B: Auspitz Sign, Berkeley’s Membrane, Grattage Sign
options.C: Berkeley’s Membrane, Grattage Sign, Auspitz Sign
options.D: Berkeley’s Membrane, Auspitz Sign, Grattage Sign

questions.explanation: Correct answer: A) Grattage sign, Berkeley’s Membrane, Auspitz Sign Explanation: While examining a patient’s psoriatic lesions during scraping with a blunt object such as the blunt edge of a glass slide, the following signs are seen. Grattage Sign/ Candle sign : Accentuation of scaling when the lesion is scraped with the blunt edge of a glass slide. ↓ Berkeley’s membrane: Formation of a thin membrane on further scraping. ↓ Auspitz sign: Formation of pin-point bleeding on scraping the Berkeley’s membrane. Another sign, "Sign of the last Hauchen" or "Sign of the Last Scale," refers to the presence of small, raised, erythematous papules that become visible after the last scale is removed from a psoriatic plaque, i.e., before the formation of Berkeley’s membrane . Reference: Rook’s Textbook of Dermatology, 9th Edition, Chapter 35, Section 9

questions.question: While examining a patient with bilaterally symmetrical, silver-white scaly lesions during your Internal Medicine practical exam, you notice that each lesion is surrounded by an area of circumferential pallor as shown in the image below. What is this sign called?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) Woronoff’s ring Explanation: Woronoff 's ring is a phenomenon where a ring-like area of lighter skin encircles fading psoriasis lesions. As described above it is seen due to vasoconstriction (due to the absence of PGE2 ) and disruption of melanogenesis (autoimmunity). It is characteristically seen in healing lesions. Auspitz sign (Option A) is seen in psoriasis, referring to pinpoint bleeding when scales are removed by scraping. Asboe-Hansen sign (Option B) can be demonstrated by the spreading of a blister by applying pressure at its edge, as seen in bullous pemphigoid Nikolsky sign (Option D) indicates the detachment of the epidermis from the dermis with slight rubbing pressure, seen in pemphigus vulgaris , SSSS , Toxic epidermal necrolysis or Lyell's disease and other blistering disorders.

questions.question: While demonstrating the Koebner phenomenon as depicted in the image below to a group of medical students, a dermatology professor explains the pseudo-Koebner phenomenon as well. Which of the following is a disease that exhibits the pseudo-Koebner phenomenon?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) Warts Explanation: The Koebner phenomenon, also known as the "isomorphic response," refers to the development of new skin lesions at sites of injury or trauma in individuals with certain dermatological conditions. The classic phenomenon is commonly observed in conditions like psoriasis and lichen planus. Pseudo-koebnerization is commonly seen in Verruca vulgaris (warts). It is named after Heinrich Koebner , a dermatologist who first described this phenomenon with psoriasis. Types of Koebnerisation Category Cause Examples Images Category 1 (True koebnerization) Development of lesions at sites of trauma. Psoriasis Lichen planus (Option A) Vitiligo Psoriasis Category 2 (Pseudo koebnerization) Non-immunological and occurs due to auto-inoculation and not trauma. Verruca vulgaris (warts) Molluscum Warts Category 3 (Occasional koebnerization) The phenomenon is infrequent or occurs only in specific circumstances. Darier disease Erythema

questions.question: As a pathologist in a prestigious private clinic, a physician contacts you for urgent feedback on a skin biopsy from a prominent politician. Suspecting psoriasis, what histopathological findings in the stratum corneum would you communicate to the attending physician?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: A) Hyperkeratosis, parakeratosis, and microabscesses Explanation: The various histopathological findings in the different skin layers seen in a patient with psoriasis are as follows. Layer Findings Image Stratum Corneum Hyperkeratosis (increased thickening of stratum corneum) Parakeratosis (retention of nuclei in stratum corneum) Munro's microabscess (collection of neutrophils Stratum Granulosum Agranulocytosis / Agranulosis (absent granular layer) Malpighian layer (Stratum Spinosum and Basale) Acanthosis (increased thickness) of stratum spinosum Kogoj's Spongiform pustules (collection of neutrophils) Rete ridges They are elongated and club-shaped ( Camel foot appearance ). Dermis Suprapapillary thinning is seen as the first histopathological sign . Dilated tortuous blood vessels. Inflammation Kogoj’s spongiform pustules (Option B) is a collection of neutrophils seen in the Malphigian layer. Camel foot appearance (Option C) is seen in Rete ridges, which are elongated. Suprapapillary thinning (Option D) is seen in the dermis.

questions.question: Match the following nail sign with its most likely cause A. Mee’s line 1. Chronic renal insufficiency B. Muehrcke's lines 2. Liver cirrhosis C. Lindsay's nails 3. Arsenic poisoning D. Terry’s nails 4. Hypoalbuminemia
questions.explanation: Correct answer: a) A-3, B-4, C-1, D-2 Explanation: The above conditions are examples of leukonychia Nail sign Causes Mees’ lines Also known as transverse leukonychia. Horizontal, transverse white lines. Seen in, Arsenic poisoning Chemotherapy Muehrcke’s lines Pairs of transverse white bands. Seen in Hypoalbuminemia. Lindsay's nails Also known as half-and-half nails. See in: Chronic renal failure Uremia Terry’s nails The proximal part is white and the distal nail appears normal and red. Seen in: Liver cirrhosis Congestive heart failure Diabetes Punctate leukonychia Seen in: Trauma Alopecia areata Leukonychia is the whitish discoloration of nails. It can be classified as true leukonychia and false leukonychia. True leukonychia False leukonychia Occurs due to defective keratinization of the nail matrix. Due to abnormal nail bed vasculature. White lines or patches over the nail that do not disappear with pressure. Whitish discoloration disappears with pressure. Lines or patches move distally with nail growth and eventually disappear. Do not disappear with nail growth. Examples: Mees’ lines, punctate lines. Examples: Terry’s nails, Muerhcke’s nails.

questions.question: A 70 year old man presents with complaints of recent hair loss. He is currently undergoing chemotherapy treatment for acute lymphoblastic leukaemia. Scalp examination reveals significantly decreased hair density compared to the previous visit. Which stage of his hair cycle is most likely affected?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: A) Anagen Explanation: The most likely diagnosis in this patient undergoing chemotherapy is Anagen effluvium, which refers to hair shedding during the anagen or growth stage of the hair cycle. Hair goes through 3 stages in its life cycle. These stages are the Anagen phase (growth phase): 86% of hair, 3 years. Catagen phase (transition phase): 1% of hair, 3 weeks. Telogen phase (falling phase): 10-13% of hair, 3 months. Anagen effluvium: Anagen effluvium refers to hair shedding in the growth phase of the hair cycle. In this phase, the affected hairs have a cessation in their mitotic activity, causing damage to the hair shaft that results in breakage and complete hair loss if the bulb is affected. The main causes of anagen effluvium are toxic or inflammatory insults from drugs, toxins, radiation, and autoimmune diseases. Infections may interrupt hair growth, resulting in a single or several bald patches. Onset is rapid after 2–3 weeks after exposure to the cause. It is a diffuse, non-scarring type of alopecia that is completely reversible after the stoppage of cause, with a delay of 3–6 months. It requires no particular treatment. Catagen (Option B) : is incorrect because it is the transitional phase (2–3 weeks) when hair growth slows and follicular regression begins. It is not the primary target in chemotherapy-related hair loss. Telogen (Option C) : is incorrect because telogen effluvium refers to hair shedding due to premature shift into the resting phase , typically seen after stress, fever, or childbirth , not chemotherapy. Onset is delayed (2–3 months) after the insult. Exogen (Option D) : is incorrect because this is the shedding phase of telogen hairs. It is a passive process and not directly disrupted by chemotherapy agents.

questions.question: A 28-year-old man complains of progressive hair thinning over the temples and crown over the past two years. There is no history of sudden hair shedding, scarring, or itching. Examination shows a receding hairline and miniaturized hairs in the affected areas. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) Androgenetic alopecia Explanation: Androgenic alopecia , a type of non-scarring alopecia, characterized by progressive hair thinning especially at the temples and crown is typical of male-pattern baldness . Hair loss is divided into cicatricial and non-cicatricial alopecias: Cicatricial alopecias Non-cicatricial alopecias Loss of hair follicle stem cells. Stem cells are not affected. Irreversible cessation of hair cycle. Damage to the hair cycle can be reversed. Dermoscopy: Absent follicular ostia. Dermoscopy: Ostia is present. Black dots may be seen. Examples: Frontal fibrosing alopecia (Option A) Folliculitis Lupus erythematosus (Option D) Scleroderma Types: Patterned: Androgenic alopecia Diffuse: Effluvium (Option B) Patchy: Alopecia areata Trichotillomania. Tinea capitis Moth-eaten alopecia. Telogen effluvium (Option B) is a nonscarring alopecia marked by diffuse, often acute hair shedding due to metabolic stress, hormonal changes, or medication. It typically resolves once the underlying cause is addressed. Reference: Rook’s Textbook of Dermatology. 9th Edition, Pages 86.47, 89.10 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK430848/

questions.question: A 32 year old man presents with a 5-week history of hair loss in a well-defined area as shown below. The hairs along the periphery of the lesion can be pulled with minimal traction. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) Alopecia areata Explanation: This patient with a positive hair pull test and patchy hair loss has alopecia areata. Alopecia areata is a T-cell-mediated autoimmune condition targeting the anagen hair bulb causing non-scarring hair loss. Clinical features include, Localized patches of hair loss on the scalp that emerge over a few weeks. It can also affect other areas, such as the beard, eyebrows, eyelashes, and extremities. Variants: Alopecia Totalis: Complete hair loss from the scalp. Alopecia Universalis: Complete hair loss from all over the body. Ophiasis: Occipital hair loss. Alopecia Totalis Exclamation-mark hair, with a narrower proximal end than the distal end, is commonly observed at the periphery of lesions and is a pathognomonic finding in

questions.question: A 28 year old female presents with concerns about hair loss and decreased hair volume, as shown below. Many members of her family also have a similar history of significant hair loss. All of the following are true about the given condition except?

options.B: It follows a polygenic mode of inheritance.
options.C: Ludwig’s grading system is used to assess severity.
options.D: Mitochondrial inheritance is the primary mode of transmission.

questions.explanation: Correct answer: D) Mitochondrial inheritance is the primary mode of transmission. Explanation: Hair loss with increased central parting and decreased hair volume is considered to be female pattern hair loss (FPHL). It is different from female pattern baldness as there is no loss of front hairline (Option A) . It is seen in androgenetic alopecia which occurs due to the involvement of multiple hormonal and genetic factors. Multiple genes have been identified for the same and hence it is considered to be of polygenic inheritance (Option B). It is commonly seen in middle-aged women with progressive loss of terminal hair over the vertex of the scalp. It presents with diffuse thinning of hair, increased hair shedding, decreased hair volume, and widening of hair

questions.question: A 35 year old male presents with concern about hair loss and gradual thinning, as seen in the picture given below. He reports that all the male members of his family has lost their hair by 45 years, What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: A) Androgenic alopecia Explanation: The patient presents with concerns about hair loss and hair thinning, with the family history suggesting the diagnosis of male pattern baldness in this patient. Male pattern hair loss (androgenetic alopecia) is common in men, characterized by progressive loss of terminal hairs on the scalp, influenced by genetics and hormones. It typically begins at the temples and crown, progressing with age. Dihydrotestosterone (DHT), derived from testosterone, shrinks hair follicles, reducing the anagen phase and miniaturizing hair. This leads to the transformation of thick terminal hair into finer, vellus hair. Symptoms include hair thinning and bitemporal recession of the hairline Bitemporal recession → vertex balding → Finally left with a band of hair in the occipital region because this area is androgen-independent. Grading: Hamilton

questions.question: A 30 year old woman has been complaining of patchy scalp hair loss for the past three weeks. Her past medical history is significant for vitiligo and thyroid disorders. On examination, she has a well-circumscribed area of hair loss over her occipital region, as shown below. Which among the following is not a feature of the disease described?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) Trichoclasis Explanation: This patient with a history of autoimmune diseases and patchy hair loss as described in the question and image is suggestive of alopecia areata. Trichoclasis is a feature of a feature of trichorrhexis nodosa, not alopecia areata. Trichoclasis: It is a transverse break in the hair shaft through a node seen in Trichorrhexis nodosa . It is a hair shaft disorder where the hair shaft is excessively fragile due to the presence of nodes. The end of the hair resembles a small paint brush with cortical fibers extruding through the fracture as shown in the image. The proximal end of the hair shaft is normal, unlike in alopecia areata. It is associated with rare genetic diseases like argininosuccinate lyase deficiency. Clinical features : Sparse, brittle, and

questions.question: The image shows a 16 year old boy brought to the clinic by his father with an unusual pattern of hair loss. History states that he has become increasingly reclusive, avoiding family gatherings and showing less interest in his usual hobbies spending most of his time alone in his room. The boy himself appears unaware of the issue and has no complaints. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: A) Trichotillomania Explanation: The boy with the above history and a characteristic Friar Tuck hair loss pattern has trichotillomania. Trichotillomania: It is a psychiatric disorder in which obsessive, recurrent pulling of one’s hair results in hair loss. It is seen in adolescents or young adults, more commonly in girls. Patchy hair loss with broken hair of variable lengths is seen in commonly accessible sites like the frontoparietal area of the scalp. In the Friar Tuck sign or Tonsure pattern, there is uneven hair loss in a circular pattern with surrounding hairs remaining unaffected. Perifollicular hemorrhages can also be seen because of trauma to the scalp. Skin biopsy shows empty hair follicles, with some forming soft twisted hairs described as tracheomalacia. Treatment includes cognitive behavioral therapy and antipsychotic medications like SSRI and paroxetine. Trichobezoar/ Rapunzel syndrome is caused by chronic ingestion of hair ; it is commonly seen in young females who may have psychological disorders, such as trichophagia and trichotillomania. Common symptoms are abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and weight loss. Netherton syndrome (Option D) is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by a mutation in the serine protease inhibitor. Characteristic triad includes, Congenital Ichtyosiform erythroderma. Trichorrhexis invaginata (Bamboo hair). Atopic diathesis. Alopecia areata (Option B)

A punch biopsy of the scalp and culture of extracted hair is the most appropriate investigation. Folliculitis decalvans: Folliculitis decalvans or tufted hair folliculitis is a progressive pattern of cicatricial alopecia of the scalp. Its characteristic feature is the presence of multiple tufts of hair emerging from a single follicular opening also known as Doll’s hair appearance The images below depict the scaring alopecia seen in Folliculitis decalvans. questions.question: A 32 year old man complains of multiple inflamed, fluctuating nodules on his scalp. He also has patchy areas of hair loss. Upon examination, you notice interconnected sinus tracts and scarring with pustular discharge as shown below. Which of the following is not associated with this disease?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) Pustular psoriasis Explanation: The above scenario with scalp lesions is seen in dissecting cellulitis of the scalp, which is part of the follicular occlusion tetrad. Pustular psoriasis is not part of the tetrad. Follicular occlusion tetrad is a group of four disorders where follicular occlusion is thought to be a key pathogenic event. The components of this tetrad are: Dissecting cellulitis of the scalp Hidradenitis suppurativa Acne conglobata Pilonidal sinus Dissecting cellulitis of the scalp: Dissecting cellulitis of the scalp (Hoffman disease) is a type of cicatricial alopecia characterized by multiple suppurative nodular lesions over the scalp. Follicular occlusion by accumulation of sebaceous and keratinous materials causes an intense neutrophilic inflammatory reaction which is exacerbated by secondary bacterial infection. The patient presents with boggy, suppurative pustules and nodules that later form sinus tracts. This leads to patchy and scarring alopecia over the scalp as shown below. Diagnosis is mainly clinical through history and examination. Cultures are done to determine the organism causing secondary infection. questions.question: A 32 year old woman presents with complaints of abnormal hair growth, as shown in the image. Which of the following drugs can be prescribed to her as oral therapy?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: D) Spironolactone Explanation: The given image shows coarse terminal hair in the face region of a woman, which suggests hirsutism. Among the given options, spironolactone is a popular treatment for hirsutism. It interferes with the production of testosterone and increases its metabolic clearance. Hirsutism refers to excessive terminal hair growth in women, which is an initial sign of a hyperandrogenic state. The hair growth is in a male pattern, occurring as a response to the presence of higher levels of testosterone. The vellus hair turns into coarse, terminal hairs. The Ferriman-Gallwey (mFG) score is a method for evaluating and quantifying hirsutism, or excess body or facial hair growth, in women.An Ferriman-Gallwey score of 8 or more was considered diagnostic of hirsutism. questions.question: A 42-year-old woman presented with complaints of a circular, scaly rash on her scalp, as shown in the image. On examination, you notice multiple small spikes over the underside of the rash. This presentation is most characteristic of which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: D) Discoid lupus erythematosus Explanation: ‘ Carpet tack sign,’ as shown in the image, is seen in discoid lupus erythematosus (DLE). Scales on the undersurface of the lesion appear like tin tacks penetrated on carpets. Discoid lupus erythematosus is the most common type of chronic cutaneous lupus erythematosus. Clinical features: Localized Skin Involvement: Predominantly affects the face and scalp, presenting as circumscribed/ discoid erythematous patches on cheeks, nose bridge, ears, neck, and scalp Lesions exhibit adherent scale with underlying horny plugs (“tin-tack” sign) due to follicular plugging. Characterized by three zones: Central Atrophy area Middle activity - perifollicular plugging, scaling, telangiectasias Zone of hyperpigmentation Schuster sign : Lesions over the ear conchae Cicatricial alopecia Scarring and pigmentary changes: Scarring (atrophic, hypertrophic, cribriform) is common. Hyper/Hypo pigmentation is also seen, especially in dark-skinned individuals. questions.explanation: Correct answer a. Heart block Explanation : A neonate presenting with facial rashes exacerbated by sunlight exposure, along with a maternal history of positive anti-Ro/SSA antibodies, is highly suggestive of neonatal lupus erythematosus (NLE). NLE occurs when maternal autoantibodies, particularly anti-Ro/SSA antibodies, cross the placenta and affect the fetus. Clinical features of Neonatal Lupus Erythematosus are: Cutaneous: Rash resembling subacute cutaneous lupus erythematosus (SCLE) or discoid lupus erythematosus (DLE). Owl’s eye sign or Racoon sign- Erythematous, slightly scaly eruption on the face and periorbital skin Cardiac: Various degrees of heart block, including first-degree, second-degree, or complete heart block. questions.question: A 32-year-old woman was recently diagnosed with cutaneous lupus erythematosus. During her review, she has come to you with a pamphlet and would like to discuss all her treatment options. Which of the following drugs are not used for the treatment of cutaneous LE?
questions.explanation: drug-induced lupus erythematosus, and hence, it is contraindicated in the treatment of cutaneous LE. It acts via the inhibition of dihydroorotate dehydrogenase. It is used to treat rheumatoid and psoriatic arthritis. Some of the most commonly implicated drugs in drug-induced LE (DILE) include: Procainamide Hydralazine Isoniazid Minocycline Quinidine Anti-TNF agents (e.g., infliximab, adalimumab) Methyldopa Propylthiouracil TNF- α inhibitors Usually, withdrawal of causative drug resolves the disease Positive anti-histone antibodie s are particularly specific for DILE Incorrect options explanation: Option b. Corticosteroids: These are the preferred first-line drugs for cutaneous lupus erythematosus due to their potent anti-inflammatory effect. They can be applied topically or administered intralesionally. Cutaneous atrophy is a common side effect of this drug, and the patient should be carefully instructed to limit the application over the skin only. Option c. Photoprotection: UV radiation is directly responsible for inducing lesions and hence, should be avoided. Sunscreens and protective clothing should be worn daily. Photoprotection also includes avoiding drugs that cause photosensitivity (e.g., Tetracyclines, Metformin, Hydrochlorothiazides, sulfonamides, etc.) Option d. Chloroquine: Antimalarial agents like chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine agents for cutaneous lupus. These drugs have an immune-modulating and photoprotective effect. questions.question: A 32-year-old woman complains that the tips of her fingers are changing from pale white to bluish-red during winter. She states that it started five years ago but has worsened recently, along with difficulty swallowing food. Which of the following findings would you also expect to find in this patient?
questions.explanation: bluish-red discoloration, along with dysphagia (difficulty swallowing), are classic symptoms associated with Raynaud's phenomenon and oesophagal dysfunction, respectively, which are features of scleroderma. CREST syndrome is a type of limited scleroderma that consists of calcinosis cutis, Raynaud phenomenon, oesophageal dysmotility, sclerodactyly, and telangiectasia Calcinosis cutis, the deposition of calcium in the skin and subcutaneous tissues is a common complication of systemic sclerosis. Von Kossa stain used for calcinosis cutis: Pitted scar on fingertips in Raynaud's phenomenon: Incorrect Options A) Hypercalcemia: While hypercalcemia can occur in certain conditions, such as hyperparathyroidism or malignancies, it is not a characteristic feature of systemic sclerosis. C) Malar Rash: A malar rash, a rash that appears on the cheeks and resembles a butterfly shape, is characteristic of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), not systemic sclerosis. D) Morphea: Morphea, a localized form of scleroderma, primarily affects the skin and does not typically involve the oesophagus or cause dysphagia (systemic sclerosis)

questions.question: A 40-year-old woman presents with a history of Raynaud’s phenomenon, arthritis, myalgia and fatigue. On examination, she has a rash on her face that spares her nasolabial folds. Her fingers appear puffy and sausage-shaped. Positive autoantibodies to anti-U1RNP along with her history are most indicative of which of the following diseases?
questions.explanation: features of cutaneous LE, scleroderma, and dermatomyositis . Anti-U1RNP antibody (anti-U1RNP) is a specific serological marker for mixed connective tissue disease (MCTD). Mixed connective tissue disease is a type of overlap syndrome where one patient will have features of multiple connective tissue diseases. Due to its non-specific presentation, autoantibody testing is fundamental. Treatment: First line: Corticosteroids show good response Second line: Hydroxychloroquine and methotrexate Incorrect options Option a. Scleroderma : While scleroderma is associated with various autoantibodies, including anti-centromere antibodies and anti-topoisomerase I (anti-Scl-70) antibodies, it is not typically associated with anti-U1 ribonucleoprotein antibodies. Scleroderma primarily presents with skin thickening, Raynaud phenomenon, and internal organ involvement.Malar rash is not a feature. Option c. Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (LE) : Systemic lupus erythematosus is primarily associated with anti-nuclear antibodies (ANA - Most sensitive), anti-dsDNA antibodies, and anti-Smith (anti-Sm - Most specific) antibodies. Option d. Dermatomyositis : Dermatomyositis is associated with various autoantibodies, including anti-Jo-1 antibodies and anti-Mi-2 antibodies. Dermatomyositis
